metadata.case_name: Udoyaram Bhaniram (Hindu Undivided Family) v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appellant was a Hindu undivided family carrying on business as piecegoods merchants in Calcutta.
Assessment relates to year 1946-47, previous year June 12, 1944 to April 24, 1945.
Appellant filed petition under s.25A of Income-tax Act, 1922 claiming partition on April 24, 1945.
Income-tax Officer enquired on May 27, 1945 into partition and income, orders on June 30, 1945: held partition true, family divided into five groups.
Dispute over six sums aggregating Rs. 2,30,346 shown as sale proceeds of ornaments.
Appellant's explanation: Jewels sold in six lots at partition, proceeds invested in business.

ITO rejected: Appellant's books show ornaments sold, Chunilal Damani's accounts show gold; weight 3422 tolas (partition agreement Ex. A) vs 3133 tolas sold; explanation of impurities rejected as negligible deduction; sales in round figures (500 tolas); no list of jewels or family accounts showing jewels.
ITO held Rs. 2,30,346 as concealed profits, included in taxable income; also imposed Excess Profits Tax.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner: Confirmed ITO findings; noted changing versions (alloy/brass then pearls/stones); jewels should have more alloy; round figures suspicious.
Family agreement Ex. A dated February 20, 1945 to divide properties among five branches; Sch. B lists jewels total 3422 tolas.

Proceedings book: Minutes Feb 23, 1945 - pearls/stones to be removed by goldsmith Inderban; Feb 28, 1945 - 289 tolas pearls/stones/copper removed, gold 3133 tolas to be sold; April 21, 1945 - gold 3133 tolas sold, proceeds credited.
Appellant sought to admit proceedings book before Tribunal, claiming filed before ITO; April 21 minutes translated as Ex. B with endorsement 'Original produced'.
Tribunal refused to admit proceedings book: Not initialled by ITO; only April 21 minutes possibly shown; prior minutes not shown.
Tribunal held Rs. 2,30,346 as secret profits; s.25A order not binding on assessment.
High Court order Dec 7, 1950 under s.66(2): Tribunal referred two questions.
High Court June 19, 1953: Q1 negative, Q2 affirmative.
SC appeals by special leave under Art. 136.
Evidence before ITO on May 27, 1945 per Ex. D: Account books, sale statements of Chunilal Damani, ledger, statements of witnesses; no mention of proceedings book for credits.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was bound by the findings of fact of the Income-tax Officer relating to the nature and division of the assets of the joint family in question which he arrived at in his enquiry under Section 25A of the Indian Income-tax Act?
Whether there was any material or evidence upon which the taxing authorities could legally hold that the amount of Rs. 2,30,346 represented undisclosed profits of the accounting year in question?

petitioner_arguments.text: In view of the order of the Income-tax Officer under s.25A, it was not open to the Department to contend that the sum of Rs. 2,30,346 does not represent the value of family jewels.
The finding of the Income-tax authorities that the said amount represents concealed profits of business is not supported by legal evidence and is, in any event, perverse.
There is no evidence that the amount in question represents profits of business, and it was therefore not chargeable to tax under the provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Proceedings book not produced before ITO for assessment under s.23; only possibly April 21 minutes for s.25A; prior minutes not relied upon.
Discrepancies in weights, round figures, changing explanations, no list of jewels support rejection of sale of family jewels story.
s.25A order only decides partition and portions, not source of income under s.23.

court_reasoning.text: s.25A enquiry limited to whether partition occurred and portions; does not decide income assessable under s.23; introduced in 1928 to prevent tax escape on division.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order under s.25A has no bearing on assessment under s.23; same officer passed both orders same day.

court_reasoning.text: Proceedings book not relied before ITO for credits (Ex. D lists evidence, no book); only April 21 minutes possibly for s.25A; not produced before AAC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal not perverse in refusing admission; finding based on evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Where assessee fails to prove source of cash receipts, ITO entitled to infer assessable nature.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Credits treated as business receipts after rejection of explanation.

holdings.text: Tribunal not bound by s.25A findings for s.23 assessment.
Evidence supports holding Rs. 2,30,346 as undisclosed business profits; finding not perverse.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. Govindarajulu Mudaliar v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessee fails to prove source of cash receipts, ITO entitled to infer assessable nature.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Partition claim under s.25A; assessment of income under s.23; reference to High Court; purpose of s.25A amendment in 1928.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1928
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced s.25A to prevent tax escape on family division.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding the Tribunal and High Court findings that Rs. 2,30,346 represented concealed business profits taxable under Income-tax Act and Excess Profits Tax Act; s.25A order not binding on assessment.

key_quotes.text: "There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amounts of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle applied to treat credits as taxable business receipts.

key_quotes.text: The question as to what the income of the family assessable to tax under s.23 would be foreign to the scope of an enquiry under s.25A.
key_quotes.speaker: court
